questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the lesion shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features of different ulcers

Features

Venous ulcer

(Option C)

Arterial ulcer

(Option A)

Neuropathic ulcer

(Option B)

Pressure ulcer

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the feet, heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful; distal pulses are not palpable, and associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

It is also known as diabetic ulcer since it is seen in diabetic patients.

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is likely to be seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased posterior tibial & dorasalis pedis pulsations

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of sensation over the foot

options.label: D
options.text: Pain on compression of the calf

questions.correct_answer: B. Loss of sensation over the foot
questions.explanation:
Venous ulcer

Arterial ulcer

Neurotrophic ulcer

Pressure ulcer

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful, and distal pulses are not palpable, and associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

Numbness

Paresthesias

Burning or loss of sensation in the foot

Diabetes mellitus (also known as diabetic ulcer)

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male chronic smoker presents with pain in the fingers for a few months. On examination, gangrenous ulcers were present in the fingers, as shown below. Investigation showed blood glucose and lipid profile within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A) Buerger’s disease

Feature

Details

Definition

Non-atherosclerotic, segmental inflammatory vasculitis affecting small & medium-sized arteries and veins.

Etiology

Strong association with tobacco use (smoking or chewing). Exact cause unknown (likely immune-mediated).

Epidemiology

Young males (20–45 years), most commonly smokers.

More common in Middle East, South Asia.

Pathophysiology
  • Inflammation leads to thrombosis and vascular occlusion.
  • Sparing of proximal arteries (unlike atherosclerosis).
  • Segmental involvement (skip lesions).

Clinical Features
  • Claudication, rest pain (foot, hands).
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon (vasospasm causing colour changes in fingers/toes).
  • Ulcers & gangrene (especially in fingers/toes).
  • Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (inflamed veins).

Diagnosis
  • Clinical diagnosis (no specific lab tests).
  • Doppler & Angiography → Corkscrew collateral vessels (pathognomonic).
  • Exclusion of other causes (diabetes, atherosclerosis, vasculitis).

Management
  1. Complete smoking cessation (most important).
  2. Vasodilators (e.g., calcium channel blockers for Raynaud’s).
  3. Antiplatelets & anticoagulants (limited benefit).
  4. Pain management (NSAIDs, opioids if needed).
  5. Amputation (for non-healing ulcers or gangrene).

Prognosis

Poor if smoking continues but stabilises with smoking cessation.

questions.text: What is the probable medical condition for an 80-year-old male who experienced pain and swelling in the calf muscle on the right side after being immobilized due to a fracture in the right inter-trochanteric region?
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) Deep vein th

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was managed upon arrival at the emergency room, with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 80/45mmHg, and exhibiting hyper-resonance on the left side of the chest, what is the appropriate action based on the findings from the chest x-ray?

options.label: A
options.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 2nd ICS

options.label: B
options.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.correct_answer: B. Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS
questions.explanation:
Correct answer B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

Tension Pneumothorax

Pathophysiology
  • D/t ‘one-way valve’ air leaks from the lung or chest wall.
  • Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any escape, collapsing and compressing the affected lung.
  • The mediastinum shifts to the opposite side, reducing venous return and compressing the opposite lung, leading to decreased cardiac output and function. This can result in sudden death.

Causes
  • Penetrating Chest Trauma.
  • Blunt Chest Trauma with parenchymal lung injury and persistent air leak.
  • Iatrogenic Lung Injury (e.g., central venepuncture)
  • Mechanical Positive-Pressure Ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Tachypnea and Tachycardia
  • Hyper-resonance and Decreased/Absent Breath Sounds
  • Resonant Percussion with severe mediastinal/tracheal shift
  • Cyanosis and Hypotension
  • Chest Pain
  • Distended Neck Veins

Emergency Management
  • Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confirmation.
  • Immediate Thoracocentesis (needle): Wide bore needle (typically a 20- or 22-gauge) in the 5th intercostal space in the safety triangle.
  • Decompression should be performed in the "safe triangle."
  • Safe Triangle Boundaries:
    • Posterior: Latissimus dorsi
    • Anterior: Lateral border of the pectoralis major
    • Inferior: A line drawn perpendicularly from the nipple to the back, just anterior to the mid-axillary line.
  • In critical situations, a finger thoracostomy can be done in the same location.
  • Nasal Oxygen for support.
  • Intercostal Tube Placement (ICT) once stable and confirmed by chest X-ray.

Additional Care

  • Antibiotics and analgesics for treatment.
  • Ventilator Support with IPPV in severe cases.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery, for which she was immobilised. Patient started complaining of leg pain on the 5th postoperative day. On examination , Homan’s sign is positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Deep Venous thrombosis

Clinical Feature

Significance

Localized tenderness

Specific for DVT; indicates inflammation along the vein.

Asymmetrical calf swelling

Common but not specific to DVT.

Erythema and warmth

Suggestive of inflammation or thrombosis.

Pain in the affected limb

Can occur with or without movement; can indicate venous obstruction.

Dilated superficial veins

May indicate compensatory circulation due to deep venous obstruction.

Homans' sign

Non-specific; Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with extended knee will cause tenderness in the calf.

Mose’s sign

Painful response to gentle squeezing of the lower calf from side-to-side.

Neuhof's Sign

Thickening and deep tenderness in the calf muscles upon palpation.

Phlegmasia Alba Dolens

DVT of the femoral vein causes painful congestion and edema of the leg with lymphangitis, which further increases edema (white leg).

Phlegmasia Caerulea Dolens

Extensive DVT in iliac and pelvic veins leading to a blue leg with possible venous gangrene or infarction.

questions.text: How is empyema thoracis treated?
questions.correct_answer: B. Chest tube drainage and antibiotics

questions.text: A man presented with a history of stab injury to the arm. On examination, there was a hematoma, and radial and ulnar pulses were not felt. A 3.5cm longitudinal tear is noted in the brachial artery. Which among the following is the best treatment option?

options.label: B
options.text: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.correct_answer: B. Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.text: A 70-year-old female patient presents with pain in the thigh during walking. Investigation reveals the following finding as given below. What will be the best surgical management?
According to the CEAP classification, What will be the stage in this patient as the patient presents with the same problem again and again?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Classification

For clinical classification:

  • No signs of venous disease
  • Telangiectasia (<1 mm) or reticular veins ( 1-3 mm dilated veins)
  • Varicose veins (>3 mm )
  • Edema
  • Pigmentation or eczema
  • LDS or atrophic blanche
  • Corona phlebectatica
  • Healed venous ulcer
  • Active venous ulcer

 

Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r.
  • C0
  • C1 (Option B ruled out)
  • C2 (Option A)
  • C3
  • C4a (Option C ruled out)
  • C4b
  • C4c
  • C5 (Option D ruled out)
  • C6

For etiological classification:

  • Congenital
  • Primary
  • Secondary (post-thrombotic)
  • No venous cause identified

 

  • Ec
  • Ep
  • Es
  • En

For anatomical classification:

  • Superficial veins
  • Perforator veins
  • Deep veins
  • No venous location identified

 

  • As
  • Ap
  • Ad
  • An

For pathophysiological classification:

  • Reflux
  • Obstruction
  • Reflux and obstruction
  • No venous pathophysiology identified

 

  • Pr
  • Po
  • Pr,o
  • Pn

questions.text: What is the appropriate course of action for managing a 25-year-old male patient who was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident? The patient has a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 80/45 mmHg. During examination, hyper-resonance is detected on the right side of the chest. Please refer to the provided chest X-ray for further evaluation.

options.label: A
options.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

options.label: B
options.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.correct_answer: B. Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS
questions.explanation:
Types of pneumothoraces:

Type

Cause

Characteristics

Common Treatment

Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

Occurs without underlying lung disease
  • Often due to rupture of apical pleural blebs
  • Seen commonly in smokers
  • Simple aspiration
  • Thoracoscopy if recurrent

Secondary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

Associated with pre-existing lung conditions (e.g., COPD)

More life-threatening due to reduced pulmonary reserve
  • Tube thoracostomy
  • Thoracoscopy or pleurodesis, if needed
  • Thoracoscopy with stapling of blebs and pleural abrasion if surgery is contraindicated

Traumatic Pneumothorax

Occurs during mechanical ventilation or resuscitation

It can be iatrogenic (from medical procedures)
  • Tube thoracostomy
  • Manage hemopneumothorax with dual chest tubes

Tension Pneumothorax

Results from physical injury (blunt or penetrating)
  • Positive pressure in pleural space
  • Severe cardiovascular compromise

Emergency treatment with large bore needle decompression followed by thoracostomy

questions.text: A bus conductor was diagnosed with varicose veins. On examination, skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis were noted. According to the CEAP classification system, he would be classified as:
questions.explanation:
CEAP (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) classification

Clinical classification:

C0

No signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectasia (<1 mm) or reticular veins ( 1-3 mm dilated veins)

C2

Varicose veins (>3 mm )

C3

Edema

C4
  • C4a - Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b - LDS or atrophic blanche
  • C4c - Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed venous ulcer

C6

Active venous ulcer

Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r.

Etiological classification:

Ec

Congenital

Ep

Primary

Es

Secondary (post-thrombotic)

En

No venous cause identified

Anatomical classification:

As

Superficial veins

Ap

Perforator veins

Ad

Deep veins

An

No venous location identified

Pathophysiological classification:

Pr

Reflux

Po

Obstruction

Pr,o

Reflux and obstruction

Pn

No venous pathophysiology identified

questions.text: In a 35-year-old individual with a history of chronic smoking who is experiencing bluish discoloration of the toes and intermittent claudication, what would be the most suitable investigation to conduct next?
questions.explanation:
Comparison of investigative modalities for peripheral arterial disease

Investigation

Advantages

Limitations

CT angiography

High resolution, 3D reconstruction, calcification detection

Radiation exposure, contrast-related risks

MR angiography

No radiation, good soft tissue contrast

Time-consuming, contraindicated in some patients (e.g., with metallic implants)

Duplex ultrasonography

Non-invasive, no radiation or contrast

Operator-dependent, limited for deep arteries

Ankle-Brachial Index

Simple, non-invasive screening tool

Limited specificity, affected by arterial calcification

questions.text: Following a fight between 2 groups, a boy was brought with severe pain in the chest, distended neck veins, dyspnea, and a BP of 80/50 mmHg. X-ray shows the following findings: What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type

Cause

Clinical Features

X-ray Findings

Tension Pneumothorax

Trauma, mechanical ventilation

Severe dyspnea, hypotension, JVD, tracheal deviation

Mediastinal shift away from affected side, hyperlucency

Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

Ruptured subpleural blebs (tall, thin males)

Sudden dyspnea, pleuritic pain

Hyperlucency without mediastinal shift

Traumatic Pneumothorax

Blunt/penetrating trauma, rib fractures

Dyspnea, pain, absent breath sounds

Hyperlucency, no mediastinal shift unless tension develops

Bilateral Pneumothorax

Rare, seen in severe trauma, barotrauma

Respiratory distress, hypoxia

Bilateral hyperlucency

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is not observed following a massive blood transfusion?
questions.explanation:
Complications of massive blood transfusion

Complication

Cause

Effect

Hypothermia

Transfusion of cold blood (stored at 4°C).

Body temperature drops, leading to impaired clotting mechanisms (coagulopathy) and worsening bleeding.

Coagulopathy

Dilution of clotting factors and platelets due to transfusion; consumption of clotting factors by ongoing haemorrhage.

Impaired blood clotting, prolonged bleeding time, increased risk of continued bleeding.

Citrate Toxicity

Large volumes of transfused blood contain citrate, which binds to calcium.

Hypocalcemia leads to muscle cramps, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Hypocalcemia

(Option A ruled out)
  • Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and other blood products are preserved with citrate, an anticoagulant.
  • Citrate binds to ionised calcium (Ca²⁺) in the recipient's blood, reducing the free calcium level - hypocalcemia

Presents as muscle spasms, cardiac arrhythmias, and decreased myocardial contractility

Hyperkalemia

(Option D ruled out)

 

 

Potassium leaks from stored red blood cells into plasma during storage.

Elevated potassium levels (hyperkalemia) can cause cardiac arrhythmias, potentially leading to cardiac arrest.

Hypokalemia

(Option C ruled out)

 

 

Potassium may shift intracellularly once transfused red blood cells are metabolically revived.

Hypokalemia, causing muscle weakness, paralysis, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Metabolic Alkalosis

Rapid metabolism of citrate into bicarbonate.

Increased pH (alkalosis) can lead to muscle twitching, irritability, and impaired oxygen release from haemoglobin.

Metabolic Acidosis

Inadequate tissue perfusion leads to lactic acid accumulation.

Lowered blood pH (acidosis) leads to confusion, fatigue, rapid breathing, and worsened cardiovascular function.

Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

Antibodies in transfused blood activate the recipient's immune response, causing inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs.

Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, presenting as acute respiratory distress with hypoxia within 6 hours of transfusion.

Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO)

Volume of transfused blood exceeds the patient’s capacity to manage, leading to fluid overload.

Pulmonary edema, shortness of breath, hypertension, and signs of heart failure.

Iron Overload

Repeated transfusions lead to excessive accumulation of iron.

Iron deposits in organs (e.g., liver, heart, pancreas), lead to organ damage and failure over time.

Hemolytic Reactions

ABO or Rh incompatibility.

Rapid destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), causing fever, chills, hemoglobinuria, and potentially acute renal failure or shock.

Allergic Reactions

Reaction to proteins in transfused blood products.

Symptoms range from mild itching, rash, or hives to severe anaphylaxis (airway constriction, low blood pressure, shock).

Bacterial Contamination

Blood products are contaminated during collection or storage.

Sepsis is characterized by fever, chills, low blood pressure, and possibly septic shock.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with IHD presents with sudden, severe, generalised abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118 bpm, rhythm is irregularly irregular, and BP is 90/60 mmHg. The abdomen appears soft and non-distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following could be a likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Acute mesenteric ischemia

Aspects

Description

Definition
  • Sudden reduction in blood supply to the intestines, leading to ischemia and potential necrosis.
  • Commonly involves the Superior mesenteric artery (SMA).

Clinical Features
  • Pain: Severe, sudden-onset abdominal pain disproportionate to physical findings.
  • Others: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bloody stools, shock.

Risk Factors
  • Cardiovascular: Atrial fibrillation, recent MI, heart failure.
  • Vascular: Atherosclerosis, vasculitis.
  • Others: Hypercoagulable states.

Radiological Features

CT Angiography: Preferred diagnostic tool; reveals SMA occlusion, String of sausage sign, bowel wall thickening, pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas.

Management
  • Initial: IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, pain control.
  • Definitive: Anticoagulation (e.g., IV heparin), surgical embolectomy, bowel resection. Vasodilators (e.g., papaverine) can be used intra-arterially to relieve vasospasm.

questions.text: What is the management approach for a 50-year-old male patient who has a 40 mm abdominal aortic aneurysm detected during his routine annual checkup?

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery is indicated if the aneurysmal diameter is > 55mm

options.label: C
options.text: Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery is indicated only if the aneurysm is > 77mm

questions.correct_answer: B. Surgery is indicated if the aneurysmal diameter is > 55mm
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Surgery is indicated if the aneurysmal diameter is > 55mm:

Management of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)

Aspect

Details

Surveillance
  • Small AAAs (3.0–3.9 cm): Monitor every 2–3 years using ultrasound.
  • Medium AAAs (4.0–5.4 cm): Monitor every 6–12 months with ultrasound.
  • Large AAAs (≥5.5 cm): Surgical intervention recommended; if not, frequent imaging and clinical review.

Medical Management

Risk Factor Modification:

  • Smoking Cessation
  • Blood Pressure Control
  • Cholesterol Management: Statins recommended.

Surgical Intervention (Option C & D ruled out)

Indications for Surgery:

  • Aneurysm Diameter ≥ 55 mm (High risk of rupture)
  • Rapid Growth: > 5 mm increase in six months.
  • Symptomatic AAAs: Consider surgery.

Surgical Options:

  • Open Surgical Repair: Using a Dacron graft, which is durable and has higher morbidity.
  • Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR): Less invasive, requires long-term surveillance for complications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding intermittent claudication is accurate?

options.label: B
options.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles

options.label: D
options.text: Relieved after getting out of bed

questions.correct_answer: B. Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Most commonly felt in the calf muscles:

Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication:

Grade

Description

Grade 0: Asymptomatic

No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise

Grade I: Mild claudication

Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade II: Moderate claudication

Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade III: Severe claudication

Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain

Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 41-year-old female patient who presented with a twisted swelling on the scalp and face, accompanied by a pulsating sensation and a bruit heard during auscultation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Cirsoid Aneu

questions.text: According to the TNM staging, a patient with lung cancer of size 2.5 cm is staged as:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - T1c:

AJCC 8TH Edition of TNM Staging of Lung Carcinoma

Primary Tumor (T)

T1

T1a(mi)

Minimally invasive carcinoma

T1a

≤ 1 cm (Option D ruled out)

T1b

1 - 2 cm (Option A ruled out)

T1c

2 - 3 cm

T2
  • Involvement of the main bronchus with the involvement of carina
  • Involvement of visceral pleura
  • Association with atelectasis or obstructive pneumonitis

 

T2a

3 - ≤4 cm (Option C ruled out)

T2b

4 - ≤5 cm

T3

 
  • > 5 - ≤7 cm OR
  • Direct invasion of the Chest wall, Phrenic nerve, Pericardium, (Or)
  • Satellite nodules in the same lobe

T4

 
  • > 7 cm in greatest dimension (Or)
  • Any tumour with invasion of the mediastinum, diaphragm, heart, great vessels, recurrent laryngeal nerve, carina, trachea, oesophagus, spine (Or)
  • Separate tumours in different lobes of the ipsilateral lung.

Lymph Node (N)

N1

Ipsilateral peribronchial and/or hilar nodes and intrapulmonary nodes

N2

Ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal nodes

N3

Contralateral mediastinal or hilar; ipsilateral/contralateral scalene/supraclavicular

Distant Metastasis (M)

M1

Distant metastasis

 

M1a

Tumor in contralateral lung or pleural/pericardial nodule/malignant effusion

M1b

Single extrathoracic metastasis, including single non-regional lymph node

M1c

Multiple extrathoracic metastases in one or more organs

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Complication of surg

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 50-year-old male who is a long-term smoker and experiences pain in both thighs and buttocks while walking approximately 500 meters?

options.label: A
options.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery

options.label: D
options.text: Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement
questions.explanation:
Vessels involved and common sites of obstruction (in Atherosclerosis)

Vessel

Common Sites of Obstruction

Related Manifestations/Findings

Aorta

Infrarenal aorta

Bilateral lower limb ischemia, absent femoral pulses

Iliac arteries

Common iliac bifurcation
  • Unilateral lower limb ischemia, absent femoral pulse.
  • Pain in the buttock is due to a block in the common iliac or aortoiliac segment (30%), often associated with impotence and is called Leriche's syndrome.

Femoral artery

Common femoral artery

Calf claudication, absent popliteal and distal pulses

Popliteal artery

Adductor canal

Calf and foot ischemia, absent pedal pulses

Tibial arteries

Proximal or mid-calf

Foot ischemia, absent pedal pulses

Subclavian artery

Proximal subclavian

Arm ischemia, absent radial/ulnar pulses.

Subclavian steal syndrome:

Obstruction of the first part of the subclavian artery can cause reverse blood flow through the vertebral artery, providing collateral circulation to the arm but affecting the posterior brain and upper limb, with steal being occult, partial, or complete.

Brachial artery

Mid-humerus level

Forearm and hand ischemia, absent radial/ulnar pulses

The patient has a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 80/45 mmHg. During examination, hyper-resonance is detected over the left side of the chest. The provided chest x-ray is shown below.

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: B. Wide bore needle insertion in the left 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain

Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

Occurs without underlying lung disease
  • Often due to rupture of apical pleural blebs
  • Seen commonly in smokers
  • Simple aspiration
  • Thoracoscopy if recurrent

Secondary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

Associated with pre-existing lung conditions (e.g., COPD)

More life-threatening due to reduced pulmonary reserve
  • Tube thoracostomy
  • Thoracoscopy or pleurodesis if needed
  • Thoracoscopy with stapling of blebs and pleural abrasion if surgery is contraindicated

Traumatic Pneumothorax

Occurs during mechanical ventilation or resuscitation

It can be iatrogenic (from medical procedures)
  • Tube thoracostomy
  • Manage hemopneumothorax with dual chest tubes

Tension Pneumothorax

questions.text: After a road traffic accident, a patient was brought to the emergency department with chest injuries. The patient's respiratory rate is elevated at 44 breaths per minute, and their blood pressure is 90/40 mm/Hg. Although conscious, the patient can only speak single words. On examination, hyper-resonance is noted on the affected side of the chest. What would be your next immediate course of action?

options.label: B
options.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.correct_answer: B. Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space
questions.explanation: Correct Option B.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 40-year-old woman who comes to the emergency room after a road traffic accident? She has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15/15, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, and an elevated jugular venous pressure. Percussion reveals hyper-resonance and decreased breath sounds in the right chest, while the left chest appears normal. However, the patient is experiencing difficulty breathing and there is bruising on the chest wall. The abdomen feels soft.

A 50-year-old diabetic man presents with a progressive increase in pain in his calf. He now prefers to sleep in a seated position by hanging his leg to alleviate pain.Pain is more in the distal part like toes and feet. It gets aggravated with movements and pressure. The pain is increased in lying down and elevation of foot; it may be reduced on hanging the foot down. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

A 62-year-old male presents with left leg swelling and pain for 5 days and has a positive D-dimer test. Duplex ultrasonography confirms an extensive DVT involving the left popliteal and femoral veins. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy?
questions.correct_answer: B. LMWH followed by oral anticoagulant
questions.explanation:
Venous Doppler with Duplex scanning

Non-invasive; detects thrombus by impaired blood flow and inability to compress veins.

  • Presence of echogenic material completely filling the lumen of vein
  • Absence of compressibility
  • Absence of blood flow

Venogram

Accurate for detecting and locating thrombus and differentiating occlusive and non-occlusive thrombus but less commonly used due to invasiveness.

Impedance Plethysmography

Measures changes in venous volume and flow using a cuff. Less useful for calf DVT and previous thrombosis.

Fibrin and Fibrinogen Assays

Measures fibrin degradation products, including D-dimer.

D-dimer has a high negative predictive value.

Radioactive Fibrinogen Study

Uses radiolabeled fibrinogen to detect thrombus. Less commonly used.

Magnetic Resonance Venous Imaging (MRVI)

Non-invasive; Useful for imaging iliac veins and IVC.

Initial Anticoagulation
  • Subcutaneous LMWH: Rapidly anticoagulate confirmed DVT cases.
  • Intravenous Unfractionated Heparin: For patients with significant renal impairment.
  • Fondaparinux or Bivalirudin: Alternatives for those with heparin sensitivity or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Transition to Oral Anticoagulation
  • Duration: At least 3 months or longer based on risk factors or recurrence.
  • Novel anticoagulants (NOACs): Rivaroxaban, Apixaban (factor Xa inhibitors), Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor).
  • Vitamin K Antagonists: Warfarin (alternative to NOACs).

Monitoring Anticoagulation
  • Heparin: Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT).
  • Warfarin: INR maintained between 2.0 to 3.0.

For Patients with contraindications to Anticoagulation

Temporary IVC Filter: Consider if bleeding risk prevents anticoagulation or to prevent pulmonary embolism. It does not treat the existing thrombus and is associated with long-term complications. (Option D)

Endovascular Surgery
  • Thrombus removal, lysis, and stenting.
  • Beneficial in selected patients, especially those with iliofemoral thrombosis, to reduce risk of chronic post-thrombotic syndrome.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presents with leg pain after walking 100 meters. On examination, there is an absent pulse in the bilateral dorsalis pedis, anterior tibial, and posterior tibial arteries, but no gangrene is noted. Intermittent claudication is suspected. Which of the following statements about this condition is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Pain is more at night and sleep

options.label: B
options.text: Pain aggravated by standing and relieved by bending forward

options.label: C
options.text: Development of pain on the 1st step of walking

options.label: D
options.text: Pain develops after walking some distance and is relieved by rest

questions.correct_answer: D. Pain develops after walking some distance and is relieved by rest
questions.explanation:
Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication:

Grade

Description

Grade 0: Asymptomatic

No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise

Grade I: Mild claudication

Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade II: Moderate claudication

Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade III: Severe claudication

Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain

Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion

questions.text: A patient presented to the outpatient department with a dilated, tortuous vein in the leg. The patient reported a history of trauma to the same area 10 years prior. Upon examination, a pulsatile vein was also noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Purpose
  • Used for hemodialysis
  • Provides high blood flow for effective dialysis

Site Selection
  • Prefer distal placement
  • Non-dominant arm is typically used

Arterial Quality

Requires a strong arterial pulse for success

Vein Preservation

Avoid placing venous lines in the arm intended for fistula

questions.text: An elderly man with a chronic history of IV drug use presents with progressively increasing swelling in the groin on the right side. The swelling is non-fluctuant but pulsatile on examination. He has diminished pulses distal to the swelling on the same side. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. CT angiography followed by surgery
questions.explanation:
Aspect

True Aneurysm

False (Pseudoaneurysm)

Definition

Involves all three layers of the arterial wall.

Involves only a layer of fibrous tissue outside the vessel.

Wall Structure

Intima, media, and adventitia are involved.

Only fibrous tissue surrounds the breach.

Morphology

Fusiform or saccular.

Typically spherical or ovoid.

Aetiology

Atherosclerosis, genetic conditions.

Trauma, surgery, or arterial puncture.

Clinical Features

May be asymptomatic until complications arise.

Often presents with a pulsatile mass or pain.

Common Locations

Large arteries (e.g., aorta, iliac).

Peripheral arteries (e.g., femoral, popliteal).

Diagnosis

Detected by ultrasound, CT, and MRI.

Detected by ultrasound or angiography.

Management

Surgical repair or endovascular techniques.

Repair or percutaneous methods (e.g., thrombin injection).

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after sustaining a stab wound to the right side of his chest. He is in acute distress, with a heart rate of 120 beats per minute, blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. On physical examination, there are decreased breath sounds on the left side. A chest X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Hemoth

questions.text: A patient presents with calf pain while walking a certain distance. The pain is severe enough that he must stop and rest before continuing. According to Boyd's grading, which of the following grades best describes this condition?
questions.explanation:
Grade

Description

Grade I

Pain develops after walking a certain distance (claudication distance). The pain subsides due to increased blood flow and collateral circulation.

Grade II

Pain persists even while continuing to walk, but the patient can still walk with effort.

Grade III

Patient must stop and rest to relieve the pain; walking becomes significantly impaired.

Grade IV

Patient experiences rest pain, and the pain persists even at rest, indicating severe arterial disease.

questions.text: A man presented with a history of stab injury over the arm. On examination, there was the presence of hematoma, and radial and ulnar pulses were not felt. A 3.5 cm longitudinal tear is noted in the brachial artery. Which of the following is the best treatment option?

options.label: B
options.text: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.correct_answer: B. Repair with great saphenous vein graft

options.text: Ectopic drainage in the iliac fossa

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Emergency Th

questions.explanation: Correct option A - Phrenic nerve:

questions.text: A patient presents with dull, aching pain and tortuous veins in both lower limbs. Which test would be appropriate for evaluating superficial femoral vein (SFJ) competence?

A 40-year-old smoker presents with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to his back, shortness of breath, and mild nausea. His BP is 190/110 mmHg, and heart rate is 105 bpm. What is the initial management?
questions.explanation:
It occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer, and creating a false lumen.

Clinical features
  • Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region
  • Renal pain and renal failure
  • Paraplegia
  • Syncope
  • Weakness
  • Hypotension or shock

Investigations

  • Stable Patient: CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice.
  • Unstable Patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm): TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography) (preferred investigation of choice)
  • MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal.
  • Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion

TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part

Management

Initial Management: Initial management of all types of aortic dissection includes:

  • Blood pressure control (which is usually high at presentation) (Option A)
  • Strict pain management,
  • Prompt referral for specialist management

Surgical Management

Type A (or type I and II) dissections

Type B (or type III) dissections

Those involving the ascending aorta usually require surgical intervention.

  • Synthetic graft if needed
  • Anastomosis

 

Endovascular stenting of type A dissections.

Initial management:

  • Antihypertensive drugs
  • Monitoring on an acute care unit

 

Complicated cases: If pain worsens, fails to resolve, or malperfusion signs appear (e.g., organ, limb, or neurological symptoms)

  • Percutaneous endovascular stents
  • Surgery (rarely used)

DeBakey Classification

(Based on the pattern of dissection)

Type I

Both ascending and descending aorta are involved

Type II

Only the ascending aorta is involved

Type III

Only the descending aorta is involved

Stanford Classification

(Based on whether the ascending aorta is involved in aortic dissection)

Type A

 

Only the ascending aorta or both ascending and descending aorta is involved.

(It includes both Type I and Type II of DeBakey’s classification)

Type B

 

Only the descending aorta is involved.

(It includes Type III of DeBakey’s classification)

questions.text: Which is the least commonly used graft for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
All of the following are anterior mediastinal tumors except:
questions.explanation:
Tumors of mediastinum

Anterior mediastinum

Middle mediastinum

Posterior mediastinum
  • Thymomas (Option D ruled out)
  • Thymic carcinomas
  • Thymic cyst
  • Germ cell tumors (Option C ruled out)
  • Lymphomas
  • Parathyroid adenomas (Option A ruled out)
  • Carcinoid tumour
  • Fibroma
  • Lymphomas (Option B)
  • Tumors of the heart and great vessels
  • Tumours of the trachea, mainstem bronchi, and oesophagus
  • Aortic pathologies such as aortic aneurysm, abscess, or dissection.
  • Pericardial cysts
  • Bronchogenic cysts
  • Neuroenteric cyst
  • Mesothelial cyst
  • Pheochromocytoma

 
  • Neurilemomas (schwannomas)
  • Neurofibromas
  • Ganglioneuromas
  • Ganglioneuroblastomas
  • Neuroblastomas
  • Pheochromocytomas

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman with no comorbidities presents with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no history of smoking or history of other illnesses. She mentions the episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Category

Description

Definition

It is characterized by episodic reduction in blood flow, typically in the fingers, triggered by cold exposure or stress.

Clinical Features
  • Pallor: Skin becomes pale or white due to reduced blood flow.
  • Cyanosis: Skin turns blue or purple due to deoxygenation of blood.
  • Rubor: Skin turns red as blood flow returns, often with swelling and tingling.
  • Cold Sensitivity: Cold, numb fingers.
  • Pain: Pain during the cyanotic phase.
  • Swelling and Tingling: Occurs in the rubor phase.

Types
  • Primary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Disease):
    • Occurs without underlying disease.
    • More common and has a better prognosis.
  • Secondary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Syndrome):
    • Occurs due to an underlying condition (e.g., scleroderma, lupus).
    • Often more severe.

Management
  • Lifestyle Modifications: Avoid cold exposure, stress reduction, and smoking cessation.
  • Medications: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine), alpha-blockers (e.g., prazosin), and other vasodilators.
  • Avoidance of Triggers: Avoid cold, beta-blockers, and caffeine.
  • Advanced Treatments: Surgical sympathectomy for severe cases.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical Presentation and History: Based on symptoms and triggers.
  • Nailfold Capillaroscopy: To examine capillary changes.
  • Blood Tests: To identify underlying autoimmune or connective tissue diseases.

questions.text: A patient with varicose veins complains of eczema in the same region. According to the CEAP guidelines, what is the stage of the clinical classification?
questions.explanation:
Class Description
C0 No visible or palpable signs of venous disease
C1 Telangiectasia or reticular veins (<1–3 mm)
C2 Varicose veins (>3 mm)
C3 Edema without skin changes
C4a Pigmentation or eczema
C4b Lipodermatosclerosis (LDS) or atrophie blanche
C4c Corona phlebectatica
C5 Healed venous ulcer
C6 Active venous ulcer
Code Description
Ec Congenital
Ep Primary
Es Secondary (e.g., post-thrombotic)
En No venous etiology identified
Code Description
As Superficial veins
Ap Perforator veins
Ad Deep veins
An No venous location identified

Code Description
Pr Reflux
Po Obstruction
Pr,o Reflux and obstruction
Pn No identifiable pathology

questions.explanation:
Type

History

Lesion Characteristics

Pain

Ischemic/Arterial

Smoking, intermittent claudication

Severe, particularly at night; relieved by dependency

Venous

Varicose veins, DVT, trauma, surgery, multiple pregnancies

Shallow, irregular/shaggy shape, granulating base, fibrinous material with moderate to heavy exudate

Mild; relieved by elevation

Neurotrophic

Numbness, paresthesias, burning, loss of sensation in the foot, DM

Punched-out, deep sinus, variable depth, partial thickness to severe, involving the tendon, fascia, joint capsule, or bone

None

Malignant Ulcer

History of skin cancer (e.g., basal or squamous cell carcinoma)

Irregular, raised borders, ulcerating tumour with hard, indurated tissue

Often painful, it can be associated with bleeding or foul odour

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Blood pressure is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
DeBakey Classification

(Based on the pattern of dissection)

Type I

Both ascending and descending aorta are involved

Type II

Only the ascending aorta is involved

Type III

Only the descending aorta is involved

Stanford Classification

(Based on whether the ascending aorta is involved in aortic dissection)

Type A

 

Only the ascending aorta or both ascending and descending aorta is involved.

(It includes both Type I and Type II of DeBakey’s classification)

Type B

 

Only the descending aorta is involved.

(It includes Type III of DeBakey’s classification)

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with pain in the calf muscles while walking. The pain subsides with rest. Which of the following is not typically seen in intermittent claudication?

options.label: A
options.text: Cramping in the muscles during exercise

options.label: B
options.text: Pain starting on taking the first step

options.label: C
options.text: The most common cause is atheroma

options.label: D
options.text: The level of occlusion cannot be decided based on symptoms

questions.correct_answer: B. Pain starting on taking the first step
questions.explanation:
Grade

Description

Grade 0: Asymptomatic

No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise

Grade I: Mild claudication

Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade II: Moderate claudication

Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade III: Severe claudication

Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain

Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion

ABI / ABPI = Systolic BP in the Ankle/ Systolic BP in the arm

Value

Interpretation

0.1 - 0.4

Critical limb ischemia

0.5 - 0.9

Intermittent claudication

1.0 - 1.2

Normal

> 1.2

Calcified vessels (seen in patients with DM, End stage renal disease)

questions.text: What is the most preferred site for the insertion of the intercostal tube drain?
questions.correct_answer: A. Upper border of lower rib
questions.explanation: Correct option A - Upper border of lower rib

questions.text: What are the distinguishing features between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax ?

options.label: D
options.text: Not improving after initial fluid resuscitation

questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Breath sou

Feature

Cardiac Tamponade

Tension Pneumothorax

Etiology

Accumulation of fluid (blood or other) within the pericardial sac, compressing the heart.

Build-up of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse and mediastinal shift.

Cause

Trauma, pericarditis, aortic dissection, myocardial infarction, etc.

Trauma, barotrauma (e.g., mechanical ventilation), lung disease, medical procedures, etc.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad: Hypotension, distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds.

Beck's triad is absent. Presents with tracheal deviation, absent breath sounds, hyperresonance on percussion, and respiratory distress.

Hemodynamic Effects

Decreased cardiac output, pulsus paradoxus (exaggerated drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration).

Decreased venous return, hypotension, and decreased cardiac output.

Imaging

Echocardiography showing pericardial effusion with right ventricular collapse ("swinging heart").

Chest X-ray showing mediastinal shift away from the affected side, reduced lung markings, and hyperinflation of the contralateral lung.

Treatment

Pericardiocentesis (draining fluid from the pericardial sac) is the definitive treatment.

Needle decompression followed by chest tube insertion (thoracostomy) to remove air from the pleural space.

questions.text: The given below device is :
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Pneumatic compression stocking

Mechanical

Pharmacological
  • Early Ambulation (simplest method)
  • Pneumatic compression Devices (MC used method)
  • Sequential compression devices 
  • Unfractionated Heparin
  • LMWH (Low molecule weight Heparin)

↓

Preferred (Because monitoring is not needed)

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown below?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Wet gangrene: 

 

Dry Gangrene

Wet Gangrene

Definition

Ischemic necrosis of tissue due to reduced blood supply

Necrosis of tissue with bacterial infection and excessive moisture

Cause

Reduced blood flow (arterial insufficiency)

Infection (usually polymicrobial) in ischemic tissue

Presentation

Dry, shriveled, and blackened tissue

Swollen, discolored (black, green, or brown), and moist tissue

Temperature

Cold to touch

Warm to touch

Pain

Painless

Can be painful

Line of demarcation

Clear line between affected and healthy tissue

Indistinct or no clear line of demarcation between affected and healthy tissue

Odor

Absent

Foul odor due to bacterial infection

Infection

Rare

Common

Progression

Slow progression

Rapid progression

Treatment

Surgical intervention (amputation) may be necessary

Immediate surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy

Prognosis

Better prognosis with early intervention

Poor prognosis due to high risk of sepsis and systemic complications

Site of obstruction

Leriche syndrome

Common femoral disease

questions.text: The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation :
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - F

 

Aneurysm

Pseudoaneurysm

Definition

Permanent dilation or bulging of a blood vessel wall, typically involving all three layers (intima, media, and adventitia)

A false aneurysm characterized by a breach in the arterial wall with blood contained by surrounding tissues

Pathophysiology

Weakness in the arterial wall leading to abnormal dilation and thinning of the vessel

Partial disruption or leakage of the arterial wall resulting in a contained hematoma

Causes

Atherosclerosis, genetic factors, connective tissue disorders, trauma, infections

Trauma, iatrogenic injury (e.g., invasive procedures), infection, arterial puncture

Location

Can occur in various arteries, including the aorta, cerebral arteries, renal arteries, and peripheral arteries

Commonly associated with arteries accessible for invasive procedures, such as the femoral artery (groin), radial artery (wrist), or brachial artery (arm)

Presentation

Often asymptomatic until rupture or compression of adjacent structures occurs

Pulsatile mass, pain, tenderness, and swelling at the site; may be accompanied by other signs of arterial injury or vascular compromise

Diagnosis

Imaging studies such as ultrasound, computed tomography (CT) scan, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), or angiography

Imaging studies, including ultrasound, Doppler ultrasound, CT scan, or angiography; may require additional assessment to distinguish from true aneurysms

Treatment

Depends on the size, location, and risk of rupture; options may include surveillance, medication, endovascular repair, or surgical intervention

Treatment options depend on the size, location, and symptoms; can include observation, ultrasound-guided compression, endovascular techniques, or surgical repair

questions.text: On the 5 th postoperative day post CABG, the patient develops tachypnea and hypotension . What is the most probable cause?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Acute respiratory failu
